posts.name: Simon Pease
posts.cooked: Can someone who uses bottom mounted electronics explain why? To me doing so poses extreme issues, such as wires getting clipped and parts being damaged. Thanks in advance!

posts.name: Matthew Gallagher
posts.cooked: We used bottom mount electronics last year because we had what was basically an inverted bellypan so we could shield them with a thinner aluminum plate. However, it didn’t work very well because the robot had to be tipped up on its intake to fix any electrical problems and for inspection, leading to a much larger hassle than originally intended. We did have some issues with disconnecting in our CAN bus but that was unrelated to electronics mounting, and never any hardware issues. In short, it can work and has in the past I just don’t recommend it because it’s a really big hassle.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
image 1920×1440 388 KB

image 1920×1440 388 KB

image 1920×1440 388 KB

Here’s a picture of 111’s bottom mounted electronics for this year. You get quite a lot of space for electronics and you don’t have to worry about putting it elsewhere, and there will normally be a ballast plate below the electronics. In my opinion, it’s much easier to access electronics underneath the robot then having to move a lot of things out of place to reach it.

111 bottom mounted electronics last year and they were pretty good, both 111 and 112 will mount our electronics under our belly pan again this year.

Two put the two reasons simply: It’s easier to package with the rest of the robot, and it’s easier to wire when the robot’s fully assembled

posts.name: Simon Pease
posts.cooked: Do you purely run your system through CAN? Otherwise how do prevent other cable from the roboRIO from being unplugged? That was my major concern.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: Yes, we only use the CAN bus to control everything. There is a metal plate underneath this that protects the electronics when it’s not being wired, so I wouldn’t be concerned about any wires being pulled out.

posts.name: Brendan Conover
posts.cooked: Also check out Code Orange 3476 BTB, there is a good shot of their brainpan.

posts.name: Simon Pease
posts.cooked: Interesting, thank you for your insight!

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
We’ve been very happy with this arrangement.  It protects the vitals inside the bumpers, helps to keep weight low, allows for easy access to everything simply by tipping the robot and removing a protective access panel, and opens up room on the top of the robot for mechanisms.

The REV stuff has small enough footprints that a whole lot can be placed on this level – for this year’s robot, we have essentially everything but our mechanisms inside the drive base, below the bumpers.  We have had zero issues with wires falling out.  If the wires fall out this way, there is another issue that needs to be fixed – robots take hard hits and things get shaken quite a bit.  The wiring needs to be reliable and not depend on gravity to keep it together.

posts.name: B Roy
posts.cooked: We always have a down facing electronics board for the sole reason of accessibility. If all your devices are in the one location, it makes it much easier to find out whats broken. As to your concern with wires clipping the ground, we jus have a lexan bellypan that covers the electronics and can be removed with a couple bolts

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked: Any cables you are concerned about falling out due to being inverted you can hot glue in, we do this for all connections.
